div.head: Letter from M.B. Summerlin to his father, Oxford Newton County Ga, Oct. 1851
div.p:
I reached Oxford the next day after leaving home: but I must tell you of my misfortune before getting here; as I came down in the night I did not know when I got to Covington. I requested the conductor too to let me know when I got there but he failed to do so and he carried me down to the Social Circle in Walton County, there I found out by inquiring that I had past Covington. I stayed there until 2 o clock in the morning and came on back to Covington. Consequently I lost my sleep and was out about six dollersdollars when I reached Oxford. The first thing I did after my arrival I took short knap of sleep. I then after waking up went over to the college building and soon got acquainted with several of the students and the faculty also, Last Monday morning I entered college, I am mighty well pleased so far with my new home , this a most beautiful little place situated 2 miles north of Covington. The college now is in a very flourishing condition, one hundred and twenty students about. But I am sorry the expenses are so much, boarding and lodging is twelve dollars per month excluding of washing,
wood and lights. I suppose there are some few that furnish the wood though they live some distance from the college. I board at the hotel about half the students board there. The expense is but very little more than boarding at private houses, all the expenses at private houses per month is about 13 1/2 dollars. At the hotel about fourteen I prefer boarding at the hotel, tuition is $30 a year, this is an extravagant place, but I suppose its as cheap as any other college in Georgia, It will cost me near $300 three hundred dollars a year to come here, it will take about $50 more than what you gave me when I left home about $23.50 for board $10.50 tuition. I have to pay a society fee but how much that is I am not permitted to say. In connection with this college as it is with all others are two literary societies which add to the improvment of the student almost as much as the college course does. the names of these societies are Phi Gamma & Few . I have joined the Phi Gamma . I will kneed some few clothing before i go home and i will have to get some books after I advance a little. We have to study a good many books here. They are very strict here. Standard Version Mr. Geo. F. Pierce is Pres. The Faculty is a very able oneDr. Means is one of the Faculty. The Faculty consists of five professors, Pres. and tutor. I have not paid my tuition yet though its
the Rule to pay it in advance. I made arrangements with the Faculty to pay it at the end of the term, for board is required in advance also. I could not pay either without depriving myself of any money the initiation fee I have to pay in about three weeks you may send me ten or fifteen dollars. As I promised to pay the board monthly, by the end of the term you can send me the rest. The term will end about the 8th December. I am sorry the Expenses are so high but its almost as little as i could make out on. I am well satisfied here. When I was in Tennessee I felt I was almost out of the world. Knoxville is a much cheaper place than this - there are many cheaper places than this but they are too far from home. I can graduate in three years and a half. I am very anxious for the sheep skin. If I had it and was worthy of it I would not take the State of Georgia for it. I would esteem it higher than all the wealth this world affords although I never expect to get it but I must get a good education before I stop if I can. I can never bear the thoughts of living and dying in ignorance. Pa I must now come to a close you must excuse my badly written letter as I had to write in a hurry farewell.
